items.title: The Donger Need Food
items.summary: Is it better to write with an empty stomach or a…
items.content_html:
Is it better to write with an empty stomach or a full one?

I am wrestling with this right now.

The topic: Optimal belly status for optimal writing.

It's probably like most things, the answer is probably somewhere in between.

After a light meal. As you nibble on a nice snack.

Or a few hours digesting a feast.

Right now, I got a meatloaf meal in my belly.

Meat.

Loaf.

Poetic.

A rare non-kimchi meal.

But it's been known to happen.

And boy, am I full, but I'm not sure I can write to my best ability.

The Donger need nap.

Of course, there is no perfect time to write or anything else.

Only windows of opportunity.

So this is mine.

I sits.

I writes.

I do not consider this a chore.

Which surprises me.

Having to do this thing every day.

But I am increasingly treating this as almost like another meal.

I have to eat.

I have to write.

Or, better put:

I get to eat.

I get to write.

A privilege.

Because that is what it is.

Now, I'm not always bringing the heat.

Somedays, I'm throwing change-ups and sliders.

This is probably my eephus.

But I'm smiling.

Belly full.

Floating a few inches off the ground.

STRIKE THREE!

Got 'em.

items.title: All Others Pay
items.summary: Everyone knocks lawyers until they need one. And sometimes even then.
items.content_html:
Everyone knocks lawyers until they need one.

And sometimes even then.

But that's true with lots of things.

Haters gonna hate.

Like this rise of "decentralized" things.

No middle men.

No oversight!

No permission!!

PURE FREEDOM!!!

Except, when they lose everything, they want a recourse.

They want justice!

And they are confused that no one can help them.

Why?

Because they didn't bake in the fact that no oversight comes with big downsides. Pure freedom rarely leads to order. Free justice is self-enforced. Often meaning you have no ability to right many wrongs.

One of the legal tenets of truly owning something is that your ownership right is recognized and defended by a mature body and system of law.

Someone wrongs you, you have the ability to fight back with the law.

And I'm seeing so many stories involving crypto scams where the only lesson is a cautionary one.

Hogs slaughtered.

And many are like, "Why isn't anyone helping me?"

Well, this is part of what they signed up for.

No one can help.

All of this is still new, relatively speaking, and more regulation and rules are kinda the antithesis of this movement.

So how do you own things in this decentralized future?

In many ways, it's caveman era stuff.

Protect your own.

Survive.

Brutal.

Me?

I like having a system of accountability.

I like ownership rights.

I don't necessarily trust all authority, but I do trust some, especially those that have my back.

More than I trust someone who says they can get rich quick and they can show me how to do it too.

More than I trust some of these folks who treat this as a religion or as a way to save the world.

It's not either, man. It's just money or something like it.

I knew something was off with this whole decentralized thing when they said the best way to technologically secure and future-proof your stuff was to write it all down on paper. Not on your computer!

Never your computer!

Paper!

Or hammer it on metal!

Or these little devices that do not connect to the internet, promise!

Trust!

Trust no one, they say, except you have to trust those selling you this stuff.

You have to trust them.

"You can trust us in a trust-no-one world."

Trust us so you don't have to trust anyone (else).

And so the irony of a trustless world is you still have to trust those who are hocking its wares and thumping its bible.

You have to trust their trustless stuff.

And that's the hard part.

"Trust no one, except all of us. We are telling the truth. And we wouldn't ever think of stealing your stuff."

Sounds familiar.

But what do I know?

DTA.

Don't trust anybody.

Even me.

items.title: Luck Factory
items.summary: How do you define luck? Success by chance rather than by…
items.content_html:
How do you define luck?

Success by chance rather than by specific action.

Have you ever met someone who was unlucky?

Someone who just couldn't seem to catch a break?

Stacking Ls like school chairs.

Eeyores.

And what about the other way?

You ever meet someone who just seemed to have a good luck charm in their taped fist?

My wife says I could fall in poop (her version is different) and still come out smelling like roses.

Which is a wonderful analogy (except the first part).

And yes, I do seem to fail upwards.

Always have.

I've always considered myself blessed.

Even when I almost died.

Especially when I almost died.

Because I have lived a good life.

Not an easy life, but a good one.

And I just felt and feel so lucky about it all.

In almost all metrics, I have overachieved.

Which is strange because anyone who knows me knows I'm an underachiever.

And if you know anything about me, it should be that.

I'm an overachieving underachiever.

Who is still walking the earth.

Hot dog.

Hot dawg.

Makes me wanna do an old man dance.

Excuse me.

[Dancing using mostly fists, shimmying shoulders, and some foot movement but not as much as you'd expect.]

Thank you.

Where was I?

Oh yes.

I've always believed you can manufacture luck.

I've had a lot of luck in my life, so I suppose it's easy for me to believe it.

But I also view many failures as lucky.

Which I don't think unlucky folk do.

I see many of my Ls as standing for Luck.

Lucky losses.

Over time, these Ls have turned into Ws.

And I either saw it right away, as it happened, or decades after.

And so I'm wondering now, if luck is more about perspective, about reframing, than about what actually happened.

Interpretation of events rather than events themselves.

Unlucky because you got hurt or lucky you didn't get more hurt?

Unlucky because you almost died or lucky you survived?

I am a lucky stoic.

Been that way, be that way, believe that way.

To out-kicking your coverage, instructive fumbles, and the infinite grace of God.

And to everything it makes possible, even the im.

游

items.title: Bystander
items.summary: I'm hitting that mid-January funk. Except instead of a new gym…
items.content_html:
I'm hitting that mid-January funk.

Except instead of a new gym membership wearout, it's this musings column.

Perhaps a little bit of the enthusiasm and luster has been lost since restarting this whole writing thing in October of '25.

A smidge.

A sprinkle.

Writing everyday is perhaps too much. Or too frequent. Or both.

It's in these days where I have nothing to say that all the growth comes from.

The hard reps.

I use hard in a very narrow sense.

This sheet easy.

What can I pluck out of thin air and make something out of nothing?

One of the basic tenets of martial arts is rhythm.

When you see two people trained to fight, it's almost like they're dancing.

One, two. One, two, three. One moves forward, the other back.

There's an order there.

That's why some wise folk say fighting a newbie or an untrained person can be very difficult.

Rookies tend to be spastic. Unpredictable. Muscly. Tight. And just chaotic.

You know what I mean?

Crazy.

And so, when you get really high up in this type of training, you learn a very advanced technique.

After you have all the moves down, you're ready to start all over.

Once you have rhythm, you must break it.

Re-introducing chaos into the order of advanced combat.

You spend years first mastering order to only then keep it spicy through mixing in chaos.

One, two, one, one, one, two, three, four, one, high kick!

Bad form, bad form, bad form, perfect execution!

I always found that funny.

At the height of controlled technique, liquid flow, of true mastery, is the most noob of tactics.

Life is like that.

In so many ways.

An apex leads you right back to the beginning.

Flailing, flailing, slap, slap, crisp cross.

Bing!

Don't try that ess with me, though.

I'm so advanced I lock my arms out to my sides (T-pose) and just start spinning.

Fools be running into these fists.

Like a top.

But, as I've said many many times, I am a man of peace.

I just like to keep things spicy.

items.title: Mirror | rorriM
items.summary: You know what my problem is? I still walk around like…
items.content_html:
You know what my problem is?

I still walk around like I'm 230.

But I'm not.

I still think I am.

And sure, all things being equal, I bring equalizers with me.

I'm like that meme of a cub looking in the mirror and seeing a lion, except I'm an old(ish) tiger looking and seeing a svelte one in their prime.

But all of that to say, I think I should realize things aren't the same anymore.

And like everything that that implies, there is some good and some not so good.

I can move quicker than ever.

But I can tell I've lost a step.

Ain't that something?

It's something.

But there's one thing I forgot to tell you about that meme. The mirror reflects your soul, not your physical.

And all I see is a smiling (smirking?) lucky mf.

游떂

items.title: Up Down Up Down Up
items.summary: We all want a life that goes straight up. Or, along…
items.content_html:
We all want a life that goes straight up.

Or, along a lifeline, up and to the right.

游닜

Like a ramp.

At the apex, you jump.

Into the ether.

Into the other side of finite.

But really, a straight line constantly going up is just a chart in a textbook.

The luckiest we can get in reality is one that goes up more often than down.

The ups make up for the downs.

This

游늳

Instead of

游늴

If you've lived a long enough lifeline, you are fortunate by that metric alone.

But you also know something about these charts, in yourself and others.

They don't make an emoji for my lifeline.

They couldn't fit the ups and downs in that sucker.

Too many pixels required.

Would look like a WWW.

This is no pity party, though.

I don't throw those.

Every down has been instructive, even and especially the destructive.

And every up has been cautionary, even in jubilance.

Blessings come in all forms.

May your life be a bunch of Ws.

And may they get bigger as you grow.

items.title: Golden Delicious
items.summary: One of my favorite things growing up in the 80s was…
items.content_html:
One of my favorite things growing up in the 80s was PBS cooking shows.

I'd like to think this is how and why I started to love to cook but really I just enjoyed their personalities.

And although some of them went horribly bad, these people were the first "influencers." PBS a YouTube of sorts for old people (and me).

An omen of what was to come.

No one's watching Justin Wilson cook to learn how to make cajun food.

You're there to hear a story.

To hear the crowd giggle.

Food was just the medium.

The side dish.

I guarantee.

The first time I saw anything on television even remotely Asian was on cooking shows. Mostly Chinese stuff, but it does stand out because I never heard anything even close to my roots (Korea wasn't mentioned at all - China was "close enough") other than in Kung Fu movies or as villains.

These things come full circle as I see my kids reaching towards items that look like them.

Identity is strong and never yielding.

游꿧 Born in the USA! I was, Born in the USA! 游꿧

Oh snap.

Where's Old Glory?

Don't get it twisted, though. I'm a real American through and through. Like Rotundo and Windham. Hulk would be proud.

Saying prayers, eating vitamins.

[Doing the Hulk up. Shaking. Shaking. You!]

游꿧 Sent me off to a foreign land 游꿧

Heck yeah!

Let's go!

游꿧 ...to go and kill the yellow man! 游꿧

Wait what?

[Looks down at skin.]

Phew, I'm gold.

Surely, they can tell the difference!

Or are they talking about Hogan? He's pretty yellow.

But yeah, I loved the 80s.

If Al can cook, so can you!

游꼩

items.title: Depends
items.summary: Have you ever known a good person to do a bad…
items.content_html:
Have you ever known a good person to do a bad thing?

What about the other way?

A bad person do a good thing?

Sure, we have.

Every day.

Everywhere we look.

So, here's what I will ask today:

How many good things can a bad person do before they are good?

And how many bad things can a good person do before they are bad?

In our society, one bad action results in a permanent label.

Whereas one good action really don't mean sheet.

You could stack a million good actions next to one big bad one and the bad will tower over all that good.

You are forever bad.

This is, I think, interesting.

Some things are unforgivable. At least by humans.

That makes sense.

A cold reality.

So the trick is, when you're bad, to not pick something unforgivable.

Sneak a late night snack.

An off color joke at the wrong time.

Dumping a bunch of tea that's taxed too highly.

Oh right.

Good and bad sometimes change meaning over time.

Even things like genuinely trying to be a good person can somehow be taken to be bad.

And vice versa.

Is bad just the absence of good?

Or something far darker?

Some of the bad apples have had my back.

Watched out for me.

And some of the "good" ...Well...

Where'd they go?

The trick is knowing how to measure it all.

Good and bad, I mean.

For the mighty fall. And the meek inherit.

I read that somewhere.

I lived it somewhere, too.

And no one's all of one or the other.

Except angels and monsters.

May you be surrounded by one, and not the other, depending on who you are.

items.title: Vigorous and Weird
items.summary: You know what's weird? Besides me. That kind of dancing professionals…
items.content_html:
You know what's weird?

Besides me.

That kind of dancing professionals do that kind of feels a little too aggressive.

Like you see them do it and instinctively get into a fighter's stance.

Kinda like rap battles but they're dissing you with their moves instead of their verses.

It's a little too in your face.

Should you be angry whilst dancing?

Angry dancing is amusing.

From mosh pits to breakers.

Another thing that's weird is that war chant thing that those lovely folks from the islands do before rugby games and city council meetings.

I mean, I get it for a sports warmup, but doing it before discussing ordinance 583-31 (item to change water sprinkler services) seems a bit, oh what's the word, ridiculous.

[Dances aggressively. Slows. Then explodes again.]

Oh snap.

[Hakas violently, hands and feet doing things, eyes bulge and widen.]

Ok, ok.

I can see some merit in this.

[Continues for far longer than necessary, extinguishing any remaining wonder or awe in it.]

I'm ready to go to war.

Next item on the agenda, proposal to paint fire trucks blue instead of red to give fire more fear.

Here we go, mother truckers.

It's on!

"You see, it's because it'll look like water!"

"But won't it confuse people with the police?"

"Light blue. Almost baby."

"Love it!"

items.title: Warship
items.summary: Welp, almost forgot to write again today. I starting writing a…
items.content_html:
Welp, almost forgot to write again today.

I starting writing a bit about worship, how we worship the wrong things, but I remembered that part of this whole thing is to realize how sacred life is.

So I erased my rant.

Instead, I would just like to say:

We all worship something.

We bow to it. Pray to it. And believe in it.

Whether it be God or money or a political party or a damn Harley.

We all have faith in something.

I know where I stand.

I know where I fall.

What do you worship?

Because we all worship something.

And how's that working out for you?

If you said, "Great!" Well, keep it up, then.

But if you said something less than positive, I wonder what it could be?

I think how you answer the worship question is about as important as who you choose to live your life with.

It's almost the same answer.

There's an old self-development trope that you are the average of the five people you spend the most time with, but I think it's really just one.

You.

Take you at your highest, take you at your lowest, and everything in between.

That's you.

You are the average of you.

You spend the most time with yourself.

If that bores you, well, you're boring.

If that excites you, well, you're crazy.

And if part of this whole deal is that everything is sacred, well what does that also imply?

You are a part of everything.

Which makes you...

游땒
